title: The Feichtinger conjecture for reproducing kernels in model subspaces

title_detail.value: The Feichtinger conjecture for reproducing kernels in model subspaces

summary:
We obtain two results concerning the Feichtinger conjecture for systems of
normalized reproducing kernels in the model subspace $K_\Theta = H^2\ominus
\Theta H^2$ of the Hardy space $H^2$, where $\Theta$ is an inner function.
First, we verify the Feichtinger conjecture for the kernels $ \tilde
k_{\lambda_n} = k_{\lambda_n}/\|k_{\lambda_n}\|$ under the assumption that
$\sup_n |\Theta(\lambda_n)|<1$. Secondly, we prove the Feichtinger conjecture
in the case where $\Theta$ is a one-component inner function, meaning that the
set $\{z:|\Theta(z)|<\varepsilon\}$ is connected for some
$\varepsilon\in(0,1)$.

THE FEICHTINGER CONJECTURE FOR REPRODUCING
KERNELS IN MODEL SUBSPACES
ANTON BARANOV & KONSTANTIN DYAKONOV
Abstract. We obtain two results concerning the Feichtinger conjecture for
systems of normalized reproducing kernels in the model subspace KΘ = H 2 ⊖
ΘH 2 of the Hardy space H 2 , where Θ is an inner function. First, we verify the
Feichtinger conjecture for the kernels k̃λn = kλn /kkλn k under the assumption
that supn |Θ(λn )| < 1. Secondly, we prove the Feichtinger conjecture in the
case where Θ is a one-component inner function, meaning that the set {z :
|Θ(z)| < ε} is connected for some ε ∈ (0, 1).

As an attempt to better understand the heart of the problem (or to find a counterexample), one may look at the Feichtinger conjecture for special systems in
function spaces. A natural class of examples is given by systems of (normalized)
reproducing kernels in Hilbert spaces of analytic functions. Let H be a reproducing kernel Hilbert space of analytic functions on some domain D, and let kλ denote
the kernel function corresponding to a point λ ∈ D, so that f (λ) = hf, kλ iH for
each f ∈ H. The Bessel property (1) for a system of normalized reproducing
kernels kλn /kkλn kH is equivalent to the Carleson-type embedding H ⊂ L2 (μ) for
the discrete measure

where δλn is the unit point mass at λn . Carleson measures are well understood
for many classical spaces (e.g., for Hardy, Bergman and Bargmann–Fock spaces),
and then the validity of the Feichtinger conjecture follows from various known
results about sampling and interpolation in these spaces.

2. Main results
In this paper we consider a class of reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces where
the problem is still open. Let H 2 denote the Hardy space of the unit disk D,
equipped with the standard norm k * k2 = k * kL2 (m) , where m is normalized
Lebesgue measure on the unit circle T. The reproducing kernels are then the
usual Cauchy kernels (1 − λz)−1 , and the Feichtinger conjecture is true. Indeed,

interpolating sequences, and each of these corresponds to a Riesz basic sequence
of Cauchy kernels. However, the problem becomes nontrivial for model (or starinvariant) subspaces of H 2 , that is, for subspaces of the form
KΘ = H 2 ⊖ ΘH 2 ,
where Θ is an inner function on the disk. These subspaces play a distinguished
role in operator theory (see, e.g., [19, 20]) and in operator-related complex analysis.

Since functions in KΘ have more analyticity than general H 2 functions, there
may exist reproducing kernels at boundary points (see Section 3 for details). We
shall denote the normalized kernel kλ /kkλk by k̃λ .
The geometry of reproducing kernels in model subspaces seems to be highly
nontrivial. No complete description is known either for Bessel sequences or for
Riesz bases, which makes the Feichtinger conjecture for these spaces a difficult
problem. The problem of describing the Carleson measures for KΘ was posed
by Cohn in 1982 and is still open, even though a number of partial results are
available [2, 3, 11, 13, 14, 15, 21]. One special case where the Carleson measures
for KΘ have been completely characterized is that of a one-component inner
function Θ. Here, by saying that Θ is one-component we mean that the set
{z ∈ D : |Θ(z)| < ε} is connected for some ε ∈ (0, 1).
The Riesz bases and Riesz basic sequences of reproducing kernels in KΘ were
described by Hruscev, Nikol'skii and Pavlov (see [18] and also [20, Part D, Chapter
4]) under the additional hypothesis that the sequence Λ = {λn } be close to the
spectrum ρ(Θ) of Θ, in the sense that

ANTON BARANOV & KONSTANTIN DYAKONOV

We are now in a position to state our main results. The first of these applies to a
general inner function Θ, provided that the Hruscev–Nikol'skii–Pavlov condition
(2) is fulfilled. The underlying Hilbert space is, of course, always taken to be KΘ .
Theorem 2.1. Every Bessel sequence of normalized reproducing kernels {k̃λn }
with property (2) splits into finitely many Riesz basic sequences.
The second theorem treats the case of a one-component inner function.
Theorem 2.2. Assume that Θ is a one-component inner function. Then every
Bessel sequence of normalized reproducing kernels {k̃λn } splits into finitely many
Riesz basic sequences.
We shall arrive at Theorem 2.2 by combining Theorem 2.1 with some stability
results (essentially due to Cohn) for Riesz bases of reproducing kernels.
It should be noted that our results carry over, via a unitary transform, to model
subspaces of the Hardy space H 2 (C+ ) in the upper half-plane C+ . In this case, the
premier example of a one-component inner function is given by Θa (z) := exp(iaz),
a > 0, and KΘa essentially reduces to the Paley–Wiener space P Wa . Precisely
speaking, if P Wa stands for the set of entire functions of exponential type at most
a that are square integrable on R, then
KΘa = P Wa ∩ H 2 (C+ ) = eiaz/2 P Wa/2 ,
and we conclude that the Feichtinger conjecture holds for reproducing kernels in
P Wa . This statement follows also from Theorem 2.1, since the sequence {λn }
generates a Riesz sequence of normalized kernels in P Wa if and only if the same
is true for the sequence {λn + i} (which satisfies (2) when λn ∈ C+ ∪ R).
Recall that the Fourier transform identifies P Wa with L2 (−a, a) and converts
the reproducing kernels kλ into the exponentials eλ (t) := exp(iλt) on the interval
(−a, a). Thus, we have
Corollary 2.3. The Feichtinger conjecture is true for any Bessel sequence of
normalized exponentials {eλn /keλn k} in L2 (−a, a).
Quite recently, Yu. S. Belov, T. Y. Mengestie and K. Seip [6] have described
the Bessel sequences and proved the Feichtinger conjecture for a class of model
subspaces in H 2 (C+ ) generated by Blaschke products with very sparse zeros. Such
inner functions are, of course, never one-component. Thus, our current results
and those of [6] complement each other.
